Expectation1: Support each other emotionally during tough times
Situation1: One sibling has just received some very difficult news and is deeply distressed by it.
Situation2: This is the last weekend before the partner relocates abroad for months.
Story: I stared at my phone, heart pounding. My sister’s text was desperate: “Can you come over? I really need you.” She’d just found out about our dad’s diagnosis, and I could hear the panic in her words. I knew she needed me—she always said I was the only one who could calm her down when things got bad. But as I read her message, my girlfriend’s laughter drifted in from the kitchen. She was making coffee, humming, her suitcase already half-packed. This was our last weekend together before she left for her new job overseas. We’d planned every minute—movies, dinner, just being close. She’d been counting on this, and so had I. I felt torn in two, guilt and worry twisting inside me. My sister needed my comfort, but my girlfriend needed my presence. I wanted to be there for both, but I could already feel myself letting someone down, no matter what I chose.
